comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: Wonder how many minks died to make those coats?

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: That's railroad magnate George Jay Gould (1864-1923): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Jay_Gould_I (One of his morbid claims to fame is that he was a victim of the "mummy's curse," dying from pneumonia soon after visiting the tomb of Tutankhamen.) The little girl is probably the ill-fated Gloria Gould Bishop Barker (1906-1943), who would marry twice before drowning in her swimming pool at 37: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gloria_Gould The other one is probably Edith Catherine Gould Wainwright MacNeal (Lady MacNeal) (1902?-1937), who also married twice before dying young; her son Stuyvesant Wainwright II (b. 1921) was briefly a Congressman. He's apparently at his sister Helen Miller Gould's 1913 wedding to Finley Johnson Shepard: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Miller_Gould

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...

comment._content: The fur worn by the children is ermine.

comment._content: very interesting ... always nice to have a look into the past :)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Helen Gould was married in January 1913 (see query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D01EFD6123BE633A... ) to Finley Johnson Shepard. www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3065181513/ is a icture of the couple in February 1913.

comment._content: edith gould is my great-great grandmother, it's fascinating to see this!

comment.author: 46317563@N04
comment._content: The George J. Gould residence was at #857 Fifth Avenue and E. 67th St. The original mansion was torn down in 1909 , the address shown is incorrect: digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm...
